content.description:
Sit start with a sloping sidepull and a crimp. Move up to a small crimp, then lock it down to a juggy mono-finger pocket. From this mono, make a hard move to a flake in the hueco-like feature. Once here, continue up the head wall on sloping pockets, sidepulls and pinches to the top of the boulder.

 Juggy monos are not typically a thing, but this critical pocket is one of the best mono-pockets ever.
content.location: Left of the middle of the trailside wall. The hueco-like feature and the mono are the obvious signs of this problem.

content.description:
This wall provides some hard pulling up an overhanging wall which leads to some technical face climbing to the top. This wall is also home to some of the hardest problems found in the area. 

  The rock quality of this wall is decent, but it isn't the super gorgeous looking white sandstone we all want it to be.
